body:
Hi!
I have the same problem. This should fix it #105

I can confirm this PR does partially fix the issue, the below image is for `near_far=(0.01, 100)` :

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/2222870/107864341-23638e00-6e53-11eb-9d72-fd209094d828.png)

So thank you for that @mihalykorodi 

However, behaviour is still quite peculiar when playing with the near part of parameter. The below image is taken with `near_far=(10, 100)` :

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/2222870/107864426-db913680-6e53-11eb-9fb4-a94f7156e294.png)

This raises the question that actually the `near_far` parameter should only address camera clipping, and another parameter should address the minimum and maximum distance thresholds for white and black pixels. In the above image, I would expect the sky to still remain white, and the nearest objects to be completely black (they are currently a mid grey in this example). The white object in the bottom left of this image is actually a result of seeing 'under' the map and viewing a far away downhill slope.

Like i said, I think camera clipping and white/black thresholds should become two separate parameters. This would allow me to create a sweet spot, where a linear scale of lightness between 0 and 255 represents a range of distances between 10 and 100 (in this example). I don't actually want objects between 0 and 10 distance to be clipped, i just want them to all be black.

Or maybe camera clipping should just be left out entirely? I don't really see a use for it for depth images, other than to reduce computational load during the decode process. A real stereo camera sensor that produces a depth image is not able to simple clip the camera in such a way, just define a distance range for which lightness values 0-255 are mapped:

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/2222870/107864617-d9c87280-6e55-11eb-97dd-19c640011a9d.png)
I've implemented this functionality using np.interp, I will soon be posting a pull request.
Thank you for the info You are right! I did not check the near part at all.

Hi, thanks for your contribution! The current submission format does not fit our workflow, so I will set up a guideline on how to contribute to our project. If you are willing to change your contribution format according to our guidelines, then we are happy to integrate it into our project. Please wait until further notice before adding any more changes. If you do not find the time to do it, we will of course fix the bug.
@pascale-commits Yeah I'm happy to change to your workflow, send me the guideline when you can. I'm guessing you'd rather me create a seperate branch and create a PR to the dev branch?
@pascale-commits I've updated the PR to merge to dev instead of master if that's all you're looking for.
Thanks, that is part of it :)

Hi :)

Thanks for your patience! We took the opportunity to set up some contribution guidelines for our repository [here](https://github.com/BeamNG/BeamNGpy/blob/dev/docs/contributing.md). This includes that users need to agree to our CLA before we can accept any pull requests. This is some unexpected administrative overhead but we hope this doesn't discourage anyone from contributing to our project.
@pascale-commits Thanks for the guidelines. I've submitted a new pull request and also agreed to the CLA (sent an email to info@beamng.gmbh) https://github.com/BeamNG/BeamNGpy/pull/110
